title: Net force acting on a block that is sliding

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are performing an experiment with the setup shown above, where a block of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sits on a horizontal table. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the table is <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is connected to a hanging object of mass <math alttext="lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over a pulley that can be considered frictionless and massless. The string connecting the two is very light and does not stretch. The students add mass to the hanging object so that <math alttext="uppercase M is greater than lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>></mo><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the block-hanging object system is released from rest. The hanging object falls for a distance <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which point it collides with the ground and comes to rest. The block on the table keeps sliding and travels a total distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="d is greater than h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>></mo><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) If the experiment were repeated where the coefficient of friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, was decreased, would the distance that the block slides after the hanging object hits the floor increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer without using or manipulating equations.

(c) A student claims that if this experiment were repeated on the moon, the distance the block slides would increase, because the frictional force would be smaller on the moon. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

(e) Students create the graph of net force on the block as a function of position for the block as shown above in Figure 2 but neglect the horizontal scale. If the students were to use an accurate horizontal scale, would the area under the force graph marked Area 1 be greater than, less than, or equal to the area under the force graph marked Area 2?
(f) During this experiment does the mechanical energy of the block-hanging object system remain constant? Justify your answer.

(g) At the beginning of the final trial, the string connecting the hanging object and the block is cut. The hanging object collides with the floor and bounces vertically, losing a third of its energy in the collision. Describe how high the object bounces in terms of <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.
